content.body: Convergent evolution in the wild.

yulia: as Jack Works points out, we have jinxed each other. I have a PR open that breaks Compartments into layers https://github.com/tc39/proposal-compartments/blob/fc3e8e0a6c1af7ffb09f111d9ddd9328aed09cf0/README.md

content.body: Which is to say, I support this potential new evolution in proposal design.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Which is to say, I support this potential new evolution in proposal design.

content.body: littledan, nicolo-ribaudo Had a conversation with Mark Miller and Peter Hoddie in which I managed fall back to my earlier position that `Module` needs to take a referrer and that the arguments of `importHook` need to be `(specifier, referrer)`, but now with a compelling argument: It should not be possible for the referrer to vary between calls to the `importHook`, and that’s best guaranteed if we capture the `referrer` given to the `Module` constructor in an internal slot that the module instance feeds back to `importHook`.
content.formatted_body: littledan, nicolo-ribaudo Had a conversation with Mark Miller and Peter Hoddie in which I managed fall back to my earlier position that Module needs to take a referrer and that the arguments of importHook need to be (specifier, referrer), but now with a compelling argument: It should not be possible for the referrer to vary between calls to the importHook, and that’s best guaranteed if we capture the referrer given to the Module constructor in an internal slot that the module instance feeds back to importHook.

littledan, nicolo-ribaudo Had a conversation with Mark Miller and Peter Hoddie in which I managed fall back to my earlier position that Module needs to take a referrer and that the arguments of importHook need to be (specifier, referrer), but now with a compelling argument: It should not be possible for the referrer to vary between calls to the importHook, and that’s best guaranteed if we capture the referrer given to the Module constructor in an internal slot that the module instance feeds back to importHook.

content.body: I may or may not successfully edit my way to that state before I present, and obviously, my goal is to reach a consistent snapshot before plenary, not to have a final answer to the design question.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: I may or may not successfully edit my way to that state before I present, and obviously, my goal is to reach a consistent snapshot before plenary, not to have a final answer to the design question.

content.body: Wait, I had a conversation with guybedford where he managed to convince me that a ModuleSource should have a referrer
This is all consistent though
content.formatted_body: This is all consistent though

content.body: Yeah, we’re likely to have conversations like that until we either get tired or separate all three layers.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Yeah, we’re likely to have conversations like that until we either get tired or separate all three layers.

content.body: That being: {text, bindings}, {{text, bindings}, referrer}, {{{text, bindings}, referrer}, memo, meta, state, &c}
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: That being: {text, bindings}, {{text, bindings}, referrer}, {{{text, bindings}, referrer}, memo, meta, state, &c}

content.body: The thing is, Module (and maybe also ModuleSource) also may need to close over the import map
Ah yes Nicolo and I have been talking about where memoization happens… also confusing

I think there are coherent stances on module blocks where `Module` instances have [[HostData]] that leads back to the host’s module map, as would be necessary to mitigate certain configuration errors, but also coherent stances where it does not.
content.formatted_body: I think there are coherent stances on module blocks where Module instances have [[HostData]] that leads back to the host’s module map, as would be necessary to mitigate certain configuration errors, but also coherent stances where it does not.

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: I think there are coherent stances on module blocks where `Module` instances have [[HostData]] that leads back to the host’s module map, as would be necessary to mitigate certain configuration errors, but also coherent stances where it does not.

I think there are coherent stances on module blocks where Module instances have [[HostData]] that leads back to the host’s module map, as would be necessary to mitigate certain configuration errors, but also coherent stances where it does not.

content.body: But, `ModuleSource` should just close over source. I’m open to adding layers and moving state around, but it would be not good to have state with the source.
content.formatted_body: But, ModuleSource should just close over source. I’m open to adding layers and moving state around, but it would be not good to have state with the source.

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: But, `ModuleSource` should just close over source. I’m open to adding layers and moving state around, but it would be not good to have state with the source.
But, ModuleSource should just close over source. I’m open to adding layers and moving state around, but it would be not good to have state with the source.

content.body: My intuition is that module blocks and module reflection probably give you the same thing. They both need a referrer, and module reflection needs multiple instantiation (which is optional for module blocks IMO)
Interesting.

> <@kriskowal:matrix.org> But, `ModuleSource` should just close over source. I’m open to adding layers and moving state around, but it would be not good to have state with the source.

OK, then, we probably need a third class which is ModuleSource + referrer, which can be instantiated multiple times, and module reflection and blocks should be this
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @kriskowal:matrix.org
But, ModuleSource should just close over source. I’m open to adding layers and moving state around, but it would be not good to have state with the source.
OK, then, we probably need a third class which is ModuleSource + referrer, which can be instantiated multiple times, and module reflection and blocks should be this

content.body: `WebAssembly.Module` definitely maps to `ModuleSource`. Those do not have referrers.
content.formatted_body: WebAssembly.Module definitely maps to ModuleSource. Those do not have referrers.

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: `WebAssembly.Module` definitely maps to `ModuleSource`. Those do not have referrers.
WebAssembly.Module definitely maps to ModuleSource. Those do not have referrers.

content.body: Guy’s proposal definitely returns something with a referrer for Wasm
Otherwise csp doesn’t work
But I agree there might be an intermediate, or that `Module` in its initial state can serve as the intermediate.
content.formatted_body: But I agree there might be an intermediate, or that Module in its initial state can serve as the intermediate.

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: But I agree there might be an intermediate, or that `Module` in its initial state can serve as the intermediate.
But I agree there might be an intermediate, or that Module in its initial state can serve as the intermediate.

content.body: Guy’s position is consistent with annotating module sources with origin information in their host data.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Guy’s position is consistent with annotating module sources with origin information in their host data.

content.body: I think we could say, WebAssembly.Module has a new internal slot, which might be empty, which is the referrer
And we can apply this to ModuleSource generally, or make it a separate class if needed
Doe’s ModuleSource have host data?
I would like to think of CSP origin as orthogonal to referrer.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: I would like to think of CSP origin as orthogonal to referrer.

content.body: In general, I think it would be nice if import module gave you something you could do import() on. This requires a referrer. Otoh a core goal of Guy’s proposal is that import module gives you something which can be multiply instantiated
content.formatted_body: In general, I think it would be nice if import module gave you something you could do import() on. This requires a referrer. Otoh a core goal of Guy’s proposal is that import module gives you something which can be multiply instantiated

content.body: 262 needs to mention referrer, but does not need to couple it to CSP.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: 262 needs to mention referrer, but does not need to couple it to CSP.

content.body: So this means, a class which has a referrer but is not an instance, if we want to meet those goals
content.formatted_body: So this means, a class which has a referrer but is not an instance, if we want to meet those goals

content.body: Referrer is sufficient for csp, and necessary for other reasons
I don’t mind thinking of that as coincidental
content.formatted_body: I don’t mind thinking of that as coincidental

content.body: Referrer on Module is sufficient, and referrer on ModuleSource is not necessary.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Referrer on Module is sufficient, and referrer on ModuleSource is not necessary.

content.body: I explained a separate reason why it is necessary above
Though origin on ModuleSource is necessary for CSP.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Though origin on ModuleSource is necessary for CSP.

content.body: I would like to think of these as different even if coincidental.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: I would like to think of these as different even if coincidental.

content.body: Sure
Going back to your conversation with Guy…
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Going back to your conversation with Guy…

content.body: I think all motivating cases are handled if `Module` captures a referrer and if there’s a way to obtain a `Module` in an uninitialized state. That’s the deferred execution proposal.
content.formatted_body: I think all motivating cases are handled if Module captures a referrer and if there’s a way to obtain a Module in an uninitialized state. That’s the deferred execution proposal.

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: I think all motivating cases are handled if `Module` captures a referrer and if there’s a way to obtain a `Module` in an uninitialized state. That’s the deferred execution proposal.
I think all motivating cases are handled if Module captures a referrer and if there’s a way to obtain a Module in an uninitialized state. That’s the deferred execution proposal.

content.body: And I’m open to deferred execution subsuming import reflection to that end.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: And I’m open to deferred execution subsuming import reflection to that end.

content.body: It would be pretty cool if these could be unified somehow
content.formatted_body: It would be pretty cool if these could be unified somehow

content.body: And I think giving it an instance which has a referrer but no instance would do it
If `import module x from 'x.wasm'` came up as a `Module`:
content.formatted_body: If import module x from 'x.wasm' came up as a Module:

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: If `import module x from 'x.wasm'` came up as a `Module`:
If import module x from 'x.wasm' came up as a Module:

content.body:
1. it would have a `referrer`
2. wouldn't be evaluated yet
3. could be duplicated for multiple instantiation: `new Module(x.source, x.referrer, etc)`
4. `x.source instanceof WebAssembly.Module`
5. `WebAssembly.Module` and `ModuleSource` can either have \[\[HostData\]\] or host-dependent variations of the Module Source Record abstract type such that they have a CSP origin
6. Could be executed with just `import(x)`

  5. WebAssembly.Module and ModuleSource can either have [[HostData]] or host-dependent variations of the Module Source Record abstract type such that they have a CSP origin
  6. Could be executed with just import(x)

content.body: Notably, in the multiple instantiation case, `referrer` can and must be differentiated from `source.[[HostData]].[[Origin]]`. Spoofing origin is no-go.
